posts.name: 2 Amy's Neapolitan Pizzeria
posts.note: Bustling wood-oven pizzeria serves innovative Neapolitan-style pies and Italian wine by the glass. They were the first certified Neapolitan pizza palce in the United States. Their wood fired pizza is the best but their side are even better. The meatballs cooked in the wood fired ovan are wonderful along with the rabbit stuffed with baby broccoli rabe and many more items that change with the season.

posts.name: A. Litteri's
posts.note: Old-school Italian grocery store and deli drawing foodies for meatball subs, homemade sausages and more. Their selection of pasta, olive oil, etc. are vast. The main reason I have been going back is for their cured Italian meats along with the service. The other things I have been know to order is their meatball sub but my favorite is the create your own cured meat sub. When I order my sub with all the extras it costs me about $13 or $14 but it's enough for two or three meals.

posts.name: Amsterdam Falafel
posts.note: Falafel on pita bread plus Middle Eastern salads and Belgian fries at a late-night quick-serve eatery. You can get a large or a small Falafel. The difference is the small has three Falafel balls and hte large has five. Once you have that you can pile on the extra ingredents until there is no more room. I suggest crushing hte Falafel balls to make more room along with it allows you to spread them out inside the pita bread.

posts.name: Baked and Wired
posts.note: Artsy neighborhood bakery and& coffeehouse supplying espresso drinks, big cupcakes and signature granola. My favorite cupcake they make is the DOOM which is dark choclate moist cake with dark chocolate fudge like frosting. The thing to ask for is if they have cake tops which are all the trimmed cake tops from the bakery with a thin layer of frosting betweeon them. Or maybe one of their ice cream sandwihces during the summer.

posts.name: Beefsteak
posts.note: Fast-casual chain from José Andrés' restaurant group specializing in flavorful veggie and grain bowls. If more restaurants made vegetables like this I would eat more of them. I ordered their beetsteak burger which is a vinegar marinated half inch to three quearters of an inch sliced beet on a toasted roll along with their special sauce some lettece greens. The other thing I ordered was their gazpacho salad which was a bunch of different greens, nuts, etc. and then cold soup poured over everything.

posts.name: Ben's Chili Bowl
posts.note: Historic spot attracts locals and celebrities for the spicy hot dogs, chili-cheese fries and milkshakes. The thing to order is the chili half smoke (half pork and half beef sausage) and an order of chili cheese fries. The chili cheese fries are big enough that two people can share.

posts.name: Big Bear Cafe
posts.note: New American restaurant with a casual interior and patio serving breakfast, lunch and candlelit dinners. I've been there on weekends for breakfast and tea.

posts.name: Bread Furst
posts.note: Bustling bakery and kid-friendly hangout offering gourmet bread, pastries, cakes, coffee and light fare. Bread Furst, is committed to offering you breads, desserts, and foods with character. Food that they love and are proud to share with everyone.

posts.name: Buffalo and Bergen
posts.note: From bagels to Knishes to egg creams this place has them. I've eatena  few of their Knishes and I like the ruben Knish, the cheese burger Knish, the pastrami Knish, and a few more.

posts.name: Carving Room
posts.note: Hip joint with a patio serving cured and carved meat sandwiches, craft beers and innovative cocktails. The items you need to order are the pastrami sandwich, chorizo cigars or the cigar sampler plate.

posts.name: Chaia
posts.note: Chaia's 'farm to taco' is a unique relationship between farmers and urban street-style food. Chaia offers seasonal, plant-based tacos, sides and natural drinks in a stylish, casual setting.

posts.name: Chinatown Express
posts.note: Family-run Chinese joint serving handmade noodles (spun in front of the window) and dumplings. The reason I go here is because they hand pull their own noodles. Which is done by an older gentleman that is probably in his 70's. I order the pork fried noodles and an order of some kind of dumpling.

posts.name: Cucina Al Volo
posts.note: Pick your pasta. Pick your sauce. To eat in or take home. Everything is handmade, from scratch. You need to try the lamb ragu or the rabbit ragu if they have them available.

posts.name: Daikaya - Izakaya
posts.note: Japanese noodle soups ladled out in casual, funky digs with yellow and blue walls and rustic tables. Have only been there for their Ramen and want to go upstairs for their Yakitori.

posts.name: Dangerously Delicious Pies
posts.note: Tiny, hip bakery serving sweet & savory pies and quiches (including vegetarian/vegan options). My favorite by far is their lemon chess pie followed by their blackberry or blueberry or one of the mixed berry pies.

posts.name: DC Noodles
posts.note: A vast variety of classic noodle and other Thai dishes are featured at this contemporary neighborhood fixture.

posts.name: DCity Smokehouse
posts.note: Hip BBQ spot serving sandwiches and combo platters. Plus, veggie sides, beer, wine, and bourbon drinks.

posts.name: Eastern Market
posts.note: Bustling marketplace since 1873 featuring a variety of produce, handmade crafts and prepared foods. Great place to walk around duing the summer to see all the fruits and vegetables, along with antiques on Sunday mornings and other arts and crafts on Saturday's.

posts.name: Ebenezers Coffeehouse
posts.note: Casual, church-owned coffeehouse featuring fair-trade coffee and tea plus live music on some evenings.

posts.name: Fast Gourmet
posts.note: Large Latin-style sandwiches are served until late at this counter at a gas station. I'm a big fan of their Cuban and their meatball sub which come with an order of matchstick french fries. Taking people here has people giving you looks because your going into a gas station to have a meal.

posts.name: Good Stuff Eatery
posts.note: Casual, multilevel upscale-industrial spot serving gourmet burgers, fries, shakes and salads. Their five napkin burger is the best. It has all kind of things but is topped off with an egg over easy.

posts.name: Granville Moore's
posts.note: Gourmet bar food like Mussels and Frites (French fries) along with a diverse beer list served in a pocket-sized space. You need to try the blue cheese mussels or the tomato sauce and sausage mussels. Plus, make sure to order Frites and different types of mussels so you can share. The big question once the food comes to the table is which direction are we passing the bowls.

posts.name: Great Wall Szechuan House
posts.note: Pan-Chinese fare with a spicy Sichuan focus in a no-frills storefront.

posts.name: Hill Country Barbecue Market
posts.note: Texas BBQ and beer served in a rustic-chic, cafeteria-style setup, with nightly live music downstairs. The things I order here the most are their smoked sausage, smoked turky, along wth brisket and a side of corn bread adn a side of Texas Caviar (black beans with a bit of red and green bell pepper and Italian dresing).

posts.name: Indigo
posts.note: Bold flavors and Indian favorites are served in a kitschy, cozy space with a large patio.

posts.name: Izakaya Seki
posts.note: Trendy option for Japanese small plates and noodle dishes, plus sizable beer list in minimalist digs. Try the monkfish liver if they have any it's like Foie gras.

posts.name: Jimmy T's Place
posts.note: Quirky, no-frills dining room serving American breakfast and lunch inside a Victorian structure.

posts.name: Keren Restaurant and Coffee Shop
posts.note: East African cuisine draws expats and locals to this upbeat hangout from breakfast until night.

posts.name: Maketto
posts.note: Food and fashion marketplace featuring java, street food and fashion from DC-based businesses. For lunch you should order the Cambodian Num Pang Sandwich (similar to Bahn Mi), the Leek Buns, and the Pork Steamed Bao. For dinner you need to order the Spicy Laab Over Bone Marrow and I see everyone ordering the Maketto Fried Chicken and Bread. Actually, I haven't found anything I wouldn't order again.

posts.name: Market Lunch
posts.note: Famous for the blue buck blueberry pancakes and a breakfast sandwich called the Brick (fried egg, cheese, potatoes, and meat (sausage, bacon, etc.) on a soft roll.)

posts.name: Mason Dixie Biscuit Co.
posts.note: Mason Dixie offers homestyle mains, such as our signature fried chicken biscuits; Benton's bacon, egg and cheddar biscuits; rich, traditional country-style sausage gravy; mouth-watering chicken pot pie gravy; nectarine, pink peppercorn jam and cracklin’ butter spreads; as well as low-country sides, like collard greens and Hoppin’ John.

posts.name: Meats and Foods
posts.note: Grilled sausage sandwiches and chili served in a small storefront with a retail market component.

posts.name: Momofuku CCDC
posts.note: David Chang offers his inventive takes on Asian fare at this airy, modern outpost next to Milk Bar. For something different at lunch time order the 'Shiitake Buns' with hoisin, scallion, cucumber and either their 'Pork Ramen' with pork belly, pork shoulder, poached egg or the 'Chilled Spicy Noodles' with Sichuan sausage, Thai basil, cashew.

posts.name: Naan and Beyond
posts.note: Takeaway and counter-service Indian meals draw fans to this popular, bare-bones spot. Make sure to get the veggie samosas with your meal or as a meal on their own.

posts.name: Panda Gourmet
posts.note: Basic cafe surroundings with a full bar where spicy Sichuan fare comes from a big menu. You need to order one the Chinese burgers along with the dumplings and porkbelly appetizers.

posts.name: Pearl Dive Oyster Palace
posts.note: Popular spot for seafood dishes with boardwalk decor and a lively upstairs bar and bocce court. Friends say the best Bloody Mary in DC.

posts.name: Pho Viet
posts.note: Neighborhood eatery serving classic Vietnamese fare on the ground floor of a brownstone. If you like dishes spicy you should order the lemongrass Pho that comes with additional chili oil.

posts.name: Peregrine Espresso
posts.note: Serious coffee sippers converge on this snug spot for carefully made espresso drinks, snacks and more. Great place to grab a coffee or a hot chocolate before wandering around Eastern Market on a weekend or to go with some food from one of the vendors or near by restaurants.

posts.name: Peregrine Espresso
posts.note: Considered by coffee connoisseurs as the premier place to go for a cup of delicious, micro brewed coffee. A wonderful place to grab a coffee, espresso, or hot chocolate to go with your food from the dozens of food choices in Union Market.

posts.name: Red Apron
posts.note: Counter-service spot in Union Market practicing whole-animal butchery to make charcuterie and more. I have order the following sandwiches: the 'Porkstrami' sandwich which contains pastrami style pork, mustard aioli, bacon braised sauerkraut, pork jus on a sub roll and the 'Meatball' sub contains pork meatballs, tomato sauce, salsa verde, and grana padano on a toasted sub roll. All their other sandwiches are great that I have eaten.

posts.name: Right Proper Brewing Company Shaw Brewpub and Kitchen
posts.note: House-made brews and Southern-influenced American eats in an industrial-chic space lined with murals. You should try the trout mousse appetizer or the deep fried chicken livers with smoked bacon, mashed potatotes, and green beans or the pasta bolognese with chopped veg and sausage.

posts.name: Stachowski's Market
posts.note: Butcher shop offering fresh and cured meats and cheeses, plus sandwiches along with roast chicken to go. You need to get the four meat grinder or the Braunschweiger: house made liverwurst on rye with onions, mustard, and sweet pickles. Another of their great sandwiches is their 'Four Meat Grinder' (sandwich) which contains capicola, mortadella, salami, soppresto, lettuce, pickled red onion, tomato, provalone, hot peppers, and more.
posts.cptn: 15 inch four meat grinder (sandwich) which contains capicola, mortadella, salami, soppresto, lettuce, pickled red onion, tomato, provalone, hot peppers, and more from Stachowski's in Georgetown

posts.name: Steak and Egg Kitchen
posts.note: Customers belly up to the counter or sit outside at this no-frills 24/7 breakfast and burger spot. It's a nice whole int he wall that always open.

posts.name: Takorean
posts.note: Union Market vendor providing fusion tacos and bowls with Korean-style BBQ fillings. The tacos are great but you need to get their Korean taco bowl with half rice and half salad along with a soft boiled egg on top.

posts.name: The Pig
posts.note: Barn wood on the walls matches the hearty barnyard cuisine at this pork-centric New American eatery. They have so many wonderful dishes to choose from. Some of my favorites are the thinly slided beets with goat cheese between each layer. Other appetizers to get are an order of the 'Face Bacon' which is fatty cut with cocoa strawberry jam, baby greens, onion marmalade or the 'Pork Belly Buns' with braised heritage pork belly, pear, and pickled cucumber.

posts.name: Thai X-ing
posts.note: This small Thai spot uses traditional recipes and offers chef's choice menus and vegetarian specials. Plus, you need to make a reservation by e-mail still I think because they don't take walk-ins. When we were there in the fall they served us a raost pumpkin/squash soup that I still think about, along with some poached fish, and other flavorful dishes.

posts.name: Thomas Sweets
posts.note: Well-known dessert shop dishing up small-batch ice cream plus frozen yogurt and handmade chocolates. They have so many flavors if you can't find one you like you're not trying hard enough. Plus, they are open late even during the week.

posts.name: Toki Underground
posts.note: Popular but snug Asian-fusion eatery known for ramen noodle soups, dumplings, sake and cocktails. My favorite is to get the curry chicken Ramen with extra noodles and if you're extra hungry also add the pork belly. Or order some panfried dumplings or if they have their sticky and spicy Asian chicken wings get those to share with others.

posts.name: Union Market
posts.note: Warehouse-like food market with a host of artisans offering charcuterie, empanadas, gelato and more. There are so many places to eat here sometimes it's hard to decide what to get. Go with a group so you can order lots of things you can share which allows you to try things and know more for next time. Plus, they have different pop-up types places worth trying.

posts.name: The Well Dressed Burrito
posts.note: Compact space with limited hours turning out classic Mexican fare for the weekday to-go lunch crowd. Hope to get here one day since they are only open Monday through Friday and from 11:45 AM to 2:15 PM.
